channel.title: Best lightweight distro for me?
channel.description:
Hey guys, I am in need of some advice on a Linux distro for an older machine. I want to optimize it's performance, so an I believe an xfce interface would be the best. I'm currently leaning toward Xubuntu, but should I try something different, such as DSL or Puppy? (or any other?)
Specs: -Intel Pentium III Processor (933MHz, 32-bit, x86) -128MB RAM -~10MB allocated as video memory -50GB hard drive space(it's going to be a dual boot. I'm looking for an installer that will fit on a single CD-R)
Oh, and what speed should I burn the iso?
Thanks in advance, Kilos
EDIT: Forgot to add: This will be my first linux, but I'm pretty good with computers, so it can't be [i]too[/i] difficult to configure and such. And if it makes a difference, my system uses FAT32 not NTFS.

[quote=“Kamu, post:16, topic:166615”][quote author=sppt link=topic=225862.msg1946053#msg1946053 date=1198355737]

Arch, but might be too advanced for a beginner.

Gentoo > Arch in both lightweightness and advancedness imo, as you have to compile your own kernel and stuff like that
[/quote]

Also takes about 10000000000x longer. No one cares about compiling your own shit, except linux geekdipshits. There is also the option to compile the software if for some bizarre reason you need to.
Gentoo is no way lightweight, you need to emerge a shitload more dependencies to compile.

From someone who has ACTUALLY used both, go Arch Linux.[/quote]
i have used both, and i think gentoo is faster.
